Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter au mieux son espace cultural pour en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Noupagagnon I group are married women, on average 41 years old with 4 children, and live mostly in polygamous households in Tamba, one of the towns in the district of Nantien in the Sikasso Prefecture, the 3rd administrative region of Mali.
They work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to properly manage their agricultural activities during the rainy season.
They are on their fifth loan with the institution, and all the previous loans were repaid properly.
Mariam, standing all the way on the left in the photo, grows peanuts, and tiger peas. 
With this loan, she intends to pay for labour costs and buy agricultural inputs and seeds to maintain 1 hectare of land.
The produce is sold throughout the town and at the Sikasso market after the harvest to a clientele composed of men and women.
She intends to realize an average profit of 50,500 FCFA for the season.
This profit will allow her to repay her loan and also help her husband provide for the family.
She hopes to maintain this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to make the best use of her farmland and generate additional income.

loans.use: To pay for labour and buy agricultural inputs and seeds.

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
As a married parent of 7 children, Cristita works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling livestock. 

Cristita is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her business of food production and vending. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda is 47 years old and married with four children. Two of her children live separately from her while the other two still live with her while they attend University and high school. Hilda's occupation is selling crafts such as handmade satchels, blankets, and hats in various places around the city of Cusco. She runs the business with her daughter Elizabeth. 

Hilda is asking for a $600 loan in order to buy more materials to make crafts. Specifically, she plans to purchase more yarn, string, and elastic bands. Hilda is a very hardworking woman and is committed to making all of the necessary loan payments on time.

loans.use: to buy more yarn, string, and elastic bands to make crafts

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna, age 47, and her husband are rice farmers. They have been cultivating rice for 20 years. During the last cropping season in May, Edna earns P30,000 from her crop. They used it for paying bills at home, paying school fees, covering daily expenses, and saving for future emergencies. For additional income, Edna also raises hogs. 

Edna and her husband have one child. 

She is now asking a loan of P28,000 in order to buy seeds and insecticides used in farming as well as to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs. With her determination and patience to succeed, she will make her crop more productive and diversify her hog-raising business for additional income. 

In the future, she would like to keep improving sales from her businesses so as to achieve financial stability.

loans.use: to buy seeds and insecticides used in farming as well as to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is from Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is 45 years old and has two children. For the past 21 years of married life, she has been selling seafood in the marketplace and dealing with different people in a favorable manner. She maintains good relationships with her fellow vendors and, topmost, to her customers. Her family has other sources of income but selling seafood is the main cash provider for the family. She earns 38,250 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from her businesses.  

Mildred is a member of GDMPC. She has already taken out several loans from the organization and repaid them well. This year, she is applying for a loan of 35,000 PHP to acquire additional seafood products to sell. This loan molds her ability to engage in business. As time goes by, Mildred aims to sustain and expand her business to increase her monthly sales rate.

loans.use: to acquire additional seafood products to sell.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es: Bertha, natural D. la ciudad D. Santa Rosa, tiene 45 años, es una mujer trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Alfredo y sus 02 queridos hijos, Nancy D. 10 y Alfredo D. 07 años, a quienes les brinda todo su respaldo. DesD. muy pequeña, Betha fue inculcada a trabajar en la chacra junto a sus hermanos, siendo sus padres  quienes le enseñaron todo lo que se tiene que hacer para lograr un buen cultivo. Ahora tiene sus propias tierras, las cuales cultiva y cuida con amor y paciencia ya que sabe que del cuidado que les brinD. a sus plantas dependerá la calidad D. sus frutos. Ella siembra plantas D. cacao y café  las cuales lleva a vender a distintas zonas D. acopio situadas en la ciudad D. Santa Rosa y San Francisco. Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es cosechar sus cultivos, ya que siente que su arduo trabajo esta dando sus frutos, lleva 23 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es cuidar sus cultivos D. la plaga D. insectos que pueden afectar la cossecha. Su mayor deseo es comprarse nuevas tierras, para incrementar su producción. Este será su crédito número 05 con MFP y en sus anteriores créditos fue muy puntual en la devolución del dinero y por ello espera D. su colaboración para seguir progresando y en su banco comunal es una socia muy solidaria con el resto D. sus compañeras. Con el dinero del crédito comprara plantas D. cacao para renovar su parcela.
texts.en:
Bertha, age 45, is a native of Santa Rosa and a hardworking woman. She lives in her own home with her husband Alfredo and their two beloved children, Nancy (age 10) and Alfredo (age 7), from whom she provides all of her support. Ever since she was a young girl, Bertha was encouraged to work in the fields along with her siblings. Her parents taught her everything she needed to know to produce a good crop. Now she has her own land that she looks after with great love and patience. Bertha knows that the quality of her output depends on the amount of care that she provides. She plants cacao and coffee and then sells her harvest to different collection centers in the cities of Santa Rosa and San Francisco. What she enjoys most about her work is harvesting her crops because she feels all of her hard work has come to fruition. Bertha has been farming for 23 years and considers the most difficult part to be protecting her crops from swarms of insects that could impact her harvest. Her greatest wish is to buy additional land so that she can increase her production.

This will be her fifth loan with MFP. Bertha was very prompt in repaying the money and hopes that the assistance from Kiva lenders will help her continue making progress. In her Communal Bank, she is very supportive of the other members. The money she requested will be used to buy cacao plants to fill her plot of land.

loans.use: to purchase cacao plants.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is a married woman with two children, both of whom are still too young for school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a fish-selling business, selling in a shop and from home to her neighbors. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a wholesale fish shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes tiene 60 años de edad, y vive con dos nietos.

Mercedes se ha dedicado al comercio desde hace más de 20 años, y lo ha hecho sola con sus hijos desde hace 11 años. Ella aprendió a manejar bien el negocio gracias a la orientación de su esposo, debido a que el comercializaba con ganado y empezó llevándole a la señora una bolsa de bocadillos, una arroba de azúcar y así poco a poco fue prosperando su negocio hasta que llego hacer fuerte.

Mercedes tiene que trasladarse a la ciudad para realizar sus compras, ella aborda un autobús que la lleve y el viaje dura alrededor de tres horas. El retorno a su casa lo hace en una mototaxi (una motocicleta que presta servicio de taxi. Cuando Mercedes hace compras más grandes, ella viaja a una ciudad más lejana y demora unas siete horas para realizar sus compras y regresar a su casa. En estas ocaciones ella aprovecha el viaje de un camión que sale una vez por semana en donde viajan todos los comerciantes de su comunidad.

Ella solicita un préstamo a Fundación Campo para mejorar su tienda. Anteriormente Mercedes dio crédito a sus clientes, lo cual es común en su comunidad, y éstos demoraron en pagarle disminuyendo la capacidad de adquisición de Mercedes. Con el préstamo ella aprovechara para comprar más productos y asi satisfacer las necesidades de los clientes. De esta forma ella mejorará sus ingresos.

En un futuro Mercedes pretende seguir mejorando su negocio para tener siempre lo necesario para sobrevivir y no depender de otros. Además, Mercedes quiere dejar un legado a sus hijos y nietos de cómo saber ganarse la vida honradamente.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 60 years old and lives with two grandchildren.  She’s been a merchant for over 20 years and has worked just with her children for the last 11 years.  She learned how to run the business well thanks to training from her husband.  Because he was a cattle merchant he started bringing her a bag of snacks or an arroba of sugar and gradually she started to make progress until her business became strong.

Mercedes has to travel to the city to make her purchases.  She boards a bus that takes her on a trip that takes three hours.  She returns home in a mototaxi (a motorcycle that provides taxi services).  When Mercedes makes larger purchases she travels to a more distant city and takes seven hours to do her shopping and return home.  On these occasions she avails herself of a truck that leaves once a week and transports all the merchants from her community.

She requests a loan from Fundación Campo to improve her store.  Mercedes previously sold on credit to her customers, a common practice in her community, but they delayed paying her which decreased Mercedes’ buying capacity.    The loan will make it possible for her to buy larger amounts of merchandise to meet customer demand thus improving her income.

In the future, Mercedes intends to continue improving her business to always have what’s necessary to survive and not be dependent on others.  Besides, Mercedes wants to leave a legacy for her children and grandchildren: that they know how to earn their livelihood honestly.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Soledad

texts.es:
Soledad es socia del Banco Comunal “Bellavista” ubicado en el distrito de Puno, provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 19 años de edad, es soltera y no tiene hijos, cuenta con estudios universitarios.
La señorita se dedica a la producción de pan, trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace un año.  Su primer préstamo fue por la suma de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invirtió en este negocio.
Con éste nuevo préstamo de S/. 1,400.00 nuevo soles, comprará harina, manteca y una parte del dinero lo utilizará para la reparación del horno ya que se acerca la fiesta de todos los santos y tendrá más pedidos.
En el negocio le ayuda su mamá y tiene maestros panaderos que trabajan para ella.
La señorita desea tener su propia panadería bien establecida y ser profesional.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal es la unión, la responsabilidad y la puntualidad de las socias.
texts.en:
Soledad is a member of the communal bank "Bellavista" which is located in the district of Puno, in the province and department of Puno. She is 19 years old, single and has no children. She has a college education.

The young lady makes bread. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for the last year. Her first loan was for S/.500.00 nuevos soles (PEN), money she invested in this business.

With this new loan of S/.1,400.00 nuevos soles (PEN), she will buy flour, butter and also use part of the loan to repair her oven as the feast of All Saints is fast approaching and she will have more orders.
.
Her mother helps her with the business and she also has master bakers working for her.

The young lady wants her own well-established bakery and to be professional.

What she likes about the communal bank is the togetherness, the responsibility and timeliness of the members.

loans.use: to buy flour, butter and repair the oven.

loans.name: Reina

texts.en: Reina is 34 years old and lives in Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has two children. Reina catches and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for months. She has requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase a second-hand pump boat to use for fishing. Reina has been a member of PMPC for five months. In the future, Reina hopes to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase a second-hand pump boat to use for fishing.

loans.name: Aggey

texts.en:
Aggey is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in Uganda. He is married and has six children with four of them currently in school. For the past three years, Aggey has been working hard to manage his bar, which sells sodas, beers and water. 

To help expand his business, Aggey has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more crates of drinks, and it will help Aggey to generate greater profits and improve his family's welfare. Aggey hopes that in the future he will be able to become the owner of a drink depot. 

Aggey is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aggey who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more crates of drinks.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is married with four children and lives in the Villaluz province of Isabela. Jonathan is a very responsible father and husband to his family. Jonathan is engaged in the farming business where he plants corn and sells it in the future.

Jonathan is requesting a loan of P 35,000 to buy seed and fertilizer that he can use on his farm. He wishes that someday his business will expand to give  his family a quality life.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Ynes Yennyna

texts.es:
Ynes es socia del Banco Comunal “Brisas del Lago” ubicado en la provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 23 años de edad, es soltera y tiene un hijo a su cargo.  Tiene estudios de educación superior.

Desde hace un año y medio trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invirtió en su negocio de venta de artesanía. Actualmente se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir.

Con éste nuevo préstamo de S/. 1000.00 nuevo soles, comprará mercaderías como: dos docenas de chompas, casacas y otros.  En el negocio le ayudan su hija y su mamá.

La señora desea tener una tienda grande donde pueda vender prendas de vestir para niños, adultos, etc.
 
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el apoyo y la unión entre las socias
texts.en:
Ynes is a member of the “Brisas del Lago” (Lake Breezes) communal bank in the district, province and department of Puno.  She is 23 years old, single, and she has one child under her care.  She has a post high school eduction.

She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for one and a half years.  She used her first loan of 300 soles to invest in her business of selling handicrafts.  She currently devotes herself to selling clothes.

With this new loan for 1,000 soles she will buy merchandise like two dozen sweaters, jackets, and other items.  Her daughter and her mother help her in the business.

She wishes to have a big store where she would be able to sell clothes for children and adults.

What she likes most about her communal bank is the support and the unity between the members.

loans.use: to buy two dozen sweaters and jackets, etc.

loans.name: Jane Mueni

texts.en:
Jane is a 23-year-old single woman who does not have children. For the past year, she has operated a pharmacy. Her business is located in a strategic location and her primary customers are all kinds of people, mostly patients. Jane describes herself as determined and ambitious. Her biggest business challenge is the high cost of medicines. 

Jane is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy more medicines. Within the next five years, her goal is to run a big hospital.

loans.use: to buy medicines

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, aged 37, is a single mother of two children, aged 10 and 12 years. She has been a dairy farmer for two years. The business earns her a monthly income of Kes.7,000.

This is her first loan with KADET. She will use the funds to purchase napier grass, a milking can and a bicycle for transporting the milk. Mary hopes to grow into a large scale dairy farmer in the future.

loans.use: To buy napier grass, milking can, bicycle

loans.name: Ariuntsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs. Ariuntsetseg, 44, sells dairy products in a market. She is widowed and lives with her son and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has been selling dairy products for 17 years and owns a stall in market.

Her monthly income often does not meet her family's necessities because both of her children study at the college and university. Their school fees are paid by herself and the costs very high, so Ariuntsetseg decided to increase her income by expanding her sales volume. The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing the dairy products from her permanent suppliers.

loans.use: to purchase dairy products from her permanent suppliers

loans.name: Elavagnon Group

texts.fr: Le groupe ELAVAGNON est composé de quatre personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Fansi Germaine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Fansi Germaine est âgée de 47 ans et vit au Bénin. Fansi Germaine a arrêté l'école au niveau primaire. Fansi Germaine est mariée à un certain Albert. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Fansi Germaine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les divers besoins de la maison. Afin d'assurer les diverses charges de la famille, Fansi Germaine vend depuis une dizaine d'année, des condiments, des conserves et des sacs de riz dans son quartier au Bénin. Fansi Germaine s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Fansi Germaine sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe ELAVAGNON, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: The Elavagnon Group is composed of four individuals living in the same neighborhood. The group’s representative, by the name of Fansi Germaine is the one raising her hand in the photo. Fansi Germaine is 47 years old and lives in Benin. Fanis Germaine stopped her schooling at the primary level. Fansi Germaine is married to a certain Albert. The couple have three dependent children, all in school. Fansi Germaine lives together with her husband and children. The couple jointly provide for the various household needs. In order to cover various family expenses, Fansi Germaine has been selling condiments, canned food and bags of rice in her neighborhood in Benin for about a dozen years. With the goal of achieving customer satisfaction and growing her sales volume and her revenues, Fansi Germaine, together with the other members of the Elavagnon group, is seeking a loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy bags of rice, canned food and condiments

loans.name: Susan's Group

texts.en:
Susan's group is comprised of hard working women. Susan is 17 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Susan has been working hard to manage her small catering business, which sells fast foods like fried fish, chips, and chicken. 

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more cooking oil and chicken for resale, and will help Susan to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Susan hopes that in the future she will be able to build a commercial house. 

Susan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil,chicken for resale

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a hardworking, honest, and warm-hearted farmer who is from the Nkubu area of Kenya, an area that has one of the best weather patterns for farming. 

Judith is the proud mother of four lovely children whom she loves, adores, and protects. Judith’s upbringing was very challenging, and because of this, she promised herself that she would work hard to get out of poverty. That is why she started farming eight years ago. Through farming, she has been able to earn a decent income. Judith is the breadwinner of her family, and this really pushes her to work hard so that her four children will have a bright future and her parents will have a comfortable life. 

Judith is seeking a loan to buy seeds and start horticulture farming so that she can use the excess space on her land. She dreams of buying more land and increasing her horticulture farming. Accessing funds is very difficult for a woman in Nkubu, but through institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, she is optimistic that her dream will be realized and her life will completely change. Through the income from horticulture farming, Judith will assure her children of a bright future and will be able to pay tuition fees for her children who depend on her. 
Through your loan, the promise of supporting small-scale farmers will be achieved.

loans.use: to buy seeds and start horticulture farming.

loans.name: Maria Nubia

texts.en:
Maria is 59 years old and lives in the municipality of Bello. She has 3 daughters whom she has raised really well and of whom she feels very proud. She has worked hard all her life to provide for her children, and she has done an amazing job in it. 15 years ago she started a sewing business where she makes clothes and other products. 

Her mother was the one who taught her everything about this job and is thanks to her that she has a talent in doing what she does. She wants to improve her sales and increase her clients so her business gets better. She’s asking for a loan so she can buy fabrics, inputs for the school season in January to make uniforms for the students.

Maria wants to keep working in her business as much as she can, but she hopes someday, she can leave the business to her daughters whom she has educated too. Help Maria to accomplish all her dreams, loan now.

loans.use: buy fabrics, inputs for the school season in January to make uniforms for the students

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Alice would like to buy shares form stock exchange market.

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.en:
When Rosa Maria was single she helped her mother in a business selling hamburgers. Now she is married and has three small children but her husband's salary, who works for a bricklayer, is not enough to provide for their family. This is why Rosa Maria opened her own hamburger business outside of her house two years ago. It has grown bit by bit and recently she acquired a small stall which needs maintenance. For this she needs a loan of $200, which she will also use to make flyers to advertise her business.

Rosa's hopes for getting ahead have made her work hard to acquire the stall she now has. She just needs a little bit of help to improve her business and her family's wellbeing. You can be an integral part of the growth of this business, don't think more about it and decide to help.

Traslated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Cuando Rosa Maria estaba soltera ayudaba a su mamá en un negocio de venta de hamburguesas. Ahora es casada, tiene tres pequeños hijos y el salario que recibe su esposo como ayudante de albañil es insuficiente para satisfacer las necesidades de su familia. Ante esta situación, hace dos años, Rosa Maria inició su propio negocio, vendiendo hamburguesas afuera de su casa, poco a poco su negocio ha ido creciendo y recientemente adquirió un pequeño puesto, que necesita mantenimiento, para lo que necesita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 200 dólares, así como para mandar a hacer volantes para dar a conocer su negocio.

Los deseos de superación de Rosa la han impulsado a trabajar muy duro y lograr tener el puesto que ahora tiene. Solo necesita de una pequeña ayuda para que ella pueda mejorar su negocio y la situación en la que vive con su familia. Tú puedes ser parte fundamental en el crecimiento de este negocio, no lo pienses más y decídete a ayudar.

loans.use: Maintenance work on stall and printing flyers to advertise

loans.name: Ruzigul

texts.en:
S. Ruzigul has been engaged in her business for 10 years. She started her present business with very small assets – little more than 1000 somoni, which she constantly develops, though she could not do in such ways as she like. The gained experience showed that to have real increase of income level, it is necessary to increase her scope of goods.

With 6 children she had not any possibility to get a higher education – she tries to avoid that situation for her own children. At present, five of them have their own families and live independently.

All her efforts and deposits are directed to her junior daughter, who lives with them. Now, she finished secondary school and plans to enter higher education. And then she also must leave her parents' house, which is their nearest goal, as it is connected with big expenditures.

loans.use: Activity extension

loans.name: Sokhoeurn

texts.en: Sokhoeurn was married in 1983 and has 5 children, 4 sons and 1 daughter. She has been in the business of planting vegetables for more than 10 years. She did not go to school but her husband, Mr. Yean Ley, studied at secondary school even though he did not finish. He is also in this farming business with his wife. With this business they have been able to send their children to school and some of them have jobs now. She bought a computer for her son to use to study at university. She has borrowed loans from MAXIMA twice. The current loan amount is for $1,000. She will use this loan to prepare the land, and purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide. With her business activity there will be no problem for her to repay the loan to MAXIMA.

loans.use: To prepare the land, and purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Mrs. Francisca H. is 62 years old and is married to Mr. Francisco Jimenez, with whom she has 3 adult children. They live in the San Francisco neighborhood of the city of Ybycui. Both come form humble backgrounds and Francisca took a job as a domestic worker early on to help her husband, who manufactured and sold charcoal briquettes, support their family.

Because their combined income was not enough to provide for their children and keep them in school, Francisca borrowed money from a sister who lived and worked in Argentina to start a new business seliing clothes door to door. Soon she was able to rent a small space and her business grew as she was able to offer a larger inventory.

This loan will be used to purchase more seasonal clothing to meet her clients' demand.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Francisca H. tiene 62 años de edad y está casada con el Señor Francisco Jiménez; tienen tres hijos, todos ellos mayores de edad, viven en el barrio San Francisco de la ciudad de Ybycuí.

Ambos provienen de familias muy humildes y como una alternativa para ayudar a su marido para la manutención de su familia consiguió trabajo como empleada domestica, ya que su marido se dedicaba a la fabricación y venta de carbón vegetal, actividad que no generaba tanto ingreso ya que dejaba poca ganancia.

Viendo la necesidad, como sus hijos ya iban creciendo y debían estudiar, y sus ingresos no eran suficientes, se animó a pedirle prestado a su hermana que trabajaba en Argentina un pequeño capital para iniciar una nueva actividad, la venta de ropas casa por casa, en poco tiempo llegó a montar un pequeño salón y así aumentó su negocio. Hoy día con mayor cantidad de inventario de mercaderías.

El préstamo será utilizado para comprar ropas de temporada, ya que cuenta con muchos clientes y el negocio es rentable.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, such as polo and dress shirts, dresses, pants, skirts, etc.

loans.name: Saidat

texts.en:
For the past 10 years, Sadait has sold chapatis from the location you see in this picture. Most likely, she has made tens of thousands of chapatis. Chapatis are a staple in the Ugandan villagers' diet and hers are delicious. She is well-known in her community and villagers visit her daily. She always has time for conversation. Sadait has raised 8 children of her own and is now raising four grandchildren.

She is 57 years old and is married. She also has a small retail shop that one of her daughters manages. There she sells staples such as sugar, posho, maize flour, baking powder, etc. From the sales of her businesses, she has been able to pay for her children's and now her grandchildren's education. She prefers to work making chapatis because it allows her to keep busy with her hands and visit with her friends in the village while she works. She has a small plot of land and she hopes one day to build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs,i.e. sugar, posho, baking powder, and salt for her retail store.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly S., age 47, is a widow who owns a mini-van transportation business, earning around $7.20 each day. She has four children, two who are married and live separately, and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase yams from the growers and resell in the market for a good profit.

loans.use: To purchase yams from the growers and resell in the market for a good profit.

loans.name: Iis

texts.en: Iis, 20, is a mother of one child.  Her husband, E., has no fixed job. To help her husband earn income she sells snacks, household goods, etc. at her small store, and earns USD15 a day. She is asking for a loan of USD75 to buy more goods for her store and as a member of MBK is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her store

loans.name: Miladinka

texts.en: Miladinka was born in 1968 and she is married. Her husband has a full-time job. They have two kids, 14 and 4 years old. Miladinka will use this loan in the amount of  US$ 900 for barn and henhouse repairs and also for buying  stones and  cement.  In this way she will expand  their little business and increase their income. She thinks that she will then be able to  ensure better life and education for her children.

loans.use: Buying building materials to repair their hen house and their barn

loans.name: Fatuma's Mishemishe Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, 32 years old, is a single woman who sells products from a kiosk, a business she started in 2006. She works everyday from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m.and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Fatuma previously concluded a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan of $775 to buy more items for her retail operation. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in timber sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Maxwell

texts.en:
Maxwell is the thirty-eight year old married father of three children. His wife also sells auto parts and is in the same trust group. Maxwell has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over eleven years. He will use the loan proceeds to purchase more clutch disks and pressure plates from Canada, Korea and the UK. In Ghana there are no auto parts stores, but there is a high demand for parts as the taxi networks are the main transportation option. His stand operates in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs who each sell specific auto parts.

Maxwell is a member of the lending group Respect. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: Maxwell would like to buy more clutch disks and pressure plates to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: As additional capital to buy more clothing for sale

loans.name: Julia Narda

texts.es:
Julia A. is a woman that puts forth effort in her work with the aim of improving the conditions of her humble home due to the fact that she has started to reconstruct it because it has been severely damaged by natural weather events. She is the mother of two school aged children whom she supports and it is her goal to provide them with a worthy roof under which to live.

Since she started the home reconstruction she has redoubled her efforts but nowadays the work has stopped due to lack of economic resources. Nevertheless, she very wisely has come to Ceprodel to obtain a loan that will permit her to purchase the construction material to continue the work. Currently she is a loyal customer of Ceprodel and has repaid her previous loans in the time established.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Julia A. es una dama que se esfuerza en su trabajo con el propósito de mejorar las condiciones de su humilde vivienda debido a que ha iniciado a reconstruirla por el hecho de que ha sido muy azotada por los fenómenos naturales. Es madre de dos hijos en edad escolar el cual mantiene y son sus metas llegar a brindarles un techo digno donde habitar.

Desde que inició con la reconstrucción de su vivienda ha duplicado sus esfuerzos pero hoy en día ha detenido la obra por falta del recurso económico. Sin embargo muy sabiamente ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito que le permita la compra de los materiales de construcción para continuar en la obra. Actualmente ella es una fiel cliente de Ceprodel habiendo cancelado sus créditos en el tiempo conveniente establecido.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Adjovi F. was born in the city of Lome in 1983. She is married and the mother of one child. In 2005, she opened a store selling hardware articles. She secured a small loan allowing her to provide additional basic household necessities for sale.

Mrs. F. is a loyal customer who is repaying her first loan on schedule. She would like to increase her business and is requesting a second loan to purchase four (4) cartons of strong glue, four (4) bundles of nails, and four (4) boxes of paint. Also, she would increase her existing inventory to provide additional sales.

Translated from French by Dave Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

Madame F. Adjovi est née en 1983 à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle a ouvert depuis 2005, un magasin de vente des articles de quincaillerie, activité à laquelle elle a ajouté la vente des produits de premières nécessités après l’obtention de son premier crédit. Elle est un client fidèle qui se comporte bien dans le remboursement. Elle désire renforcer son activité et sollicite ce second crédit pour acheter quatre cartons de colle forte, quatre paquets de cloue et quatre boîtes de peinture. Ainsi elle augmentera son stock et pourra mieux vendre.

loans.use: Purchase of hardware articles

loans.name: Massiratou

texts.fr:
Born around 1961 in Porto-Novo in the department of Ouémé, southeastern Benin, Mrs. Massiratou S. is married and the mother of four children, of whom Faoziath and Kabil, in 10th and 8th grades respectively, are still in her care. She sells electrical equipment and hardware in a store not far from her home in Avotrou. In order to meet the ever-growing demand of her customers, whom she can no longer satisfy due to lack of capital, she is requesting a loan to buy inventory and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Née vers les années 1961 à Porto-Novo dans le département de l'Ouémé au Sud-est du Bénin, dame S. Massiratou est mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont Faoziath et Kabil respectivement en classe de seconde et de quatrième au cours secondaire sont encore à sa charge. Elle est revendeuse des matériaux d'électricité et de quincaillerie dans une boutique non loin de sa résidence à d'Avotrou. Afin de contenir la demande sans cesse croissante de clients qu'elle n'arrive plus à satisfaire pour raison d'insuffisance de capital , elle sollicite ce prêt pour s'approvisionner et renforcer son activité.

loans.use: To buy 10 rolls of electrical cord and miscellaneous electrical items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a wider variety of goods for wholesaling

loans.name: Miriama

texts.en:
Miriama T., 49 and married with six children, has many years of experience in the banana plantation and shop businesses, selling to the general public six days per week. She has proven herself to be responsible borrower from previous loans with SPBD, and is now requesting a new loan to purchase chemicals, fertilizers, pesticide, and sacks of sugar, rice and flour.

SPBD loans are Miriama's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for loans from the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, fertilizers, pesticide, sacks of sugar, rice and flour

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en:
Yashar S. is a 41-year-old man who runs a barber shop in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He is a very polite and respectful hairdresser and he has many permanent clients. His training allows him to serve only male clients. 

Yashar starts his work at 8:00 in the morning and finishes between 9:00 and 10:00 at night. His busiest time is from 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m., because many of his clients come after work. 

Yashar is married and has three children. All of his efforts are designed to improve their lives and provide them with an excellent education. He would also like to teach one of his two sons his profession, so that his business can grow some day. 

Yashar has applied for a loan of $1200 to purchase modern tools for haircutting and, most importantly, to supply water to his barber shop.

loans.use: To purchase modern tools for haircuts and a water supply for his barber shop

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica A. Boateng is 22 years old; she is unmarried with no children. Veronica is a distributor and a supplier of phone credits at a very busy market in Teshie in Accra where she lives. She takes delivery from the telecommunication industries such as MTN, Onetouch, Tigo, and others who also provide the same services and supplies to retailers. Veronica has been in this business for the past year with valuable experience in the field.

Veronica A. Boateng requests a loan to buy a bigger supply of mobile phone credits/units. She also believes the loan would allow her to rent a store to sell mobile phones. Veronica would be grateful for the loan.

She belongs to the community group called ‘Abrabopa’ (meaning Good Life) Trust Group. Members in this group provide assistance to each other to access and repay loans. She does not sell on the days the group meets. Her picture was taken during one of the group meetings.

loans.use: Purchase bulk supply of phone credits

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
El joven Victor M. tiene 24 años de edad, es soltero, vive con su madre y hermanos, en la casa familiar, donde también se encuentra la microempresa. 
Es estudiante de la Universidad Nacional de Asunción en la facultad de ciencias contables. 
Desde diciembre del 2007, luego de la muerte de su padre se hace responsable de la administración de la empresa familiar, con la ayuda de su madre.  
Posee una carpintería-mueblería, donde fabrican muebles sobre pedido a  medida.
La empresa esta en el ramo desde 1985 y ahora además de fabricar los muebles, comercializan otros artículos tales como sillas de oficina, colchones y muebles de formica.
Es un joven emprendedor, pues aparte de llevar adelante la empresa de su familia, realiza trabajos de contabilidad para otras empresas.
texts.en:
Victor M. is 24 years old, single, and lives with his mother and siblings in the family’s home where we also find his business. He is a student at the Asunción National University studying accounting. After his father’s death in December 2007 he has become responsible for managing the family business, with his mother’s help. He owns a carpentry-furniture business, where he makes furniture to order. The business has been open since 1985 and now in addition to making furniture they sell other items such as office chairs, mattresses, and Formica furniture. He is an enterprising young man, in addition to carrying forward the family business he is handling the accounting for other businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood to make furniture, matresses, office chairs, etc.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en: Nilda R., 39 years old lives in Rizal Avenue, Ozamiz City. She is married to Danilo and blessed with 5 children: the eldest is a high school student, 3 are in elementary grades, and the youngest is not yet in school. The family's source of income is from carenderia (small restaurant) while her husband is also a photographer and videographer. Nilda's carenderia started in January of 2006 with a profit of 800.00 pesos. At that time, they could not afford to provide the menu they desired. The family values their carenderia and tries to maintain a quality service. They manage to survive even when there is strong competition. They increased the number of options on the menu to give the customers more choices and as a result, private and public employees, students, and other commuters started dropping in. Paglaum has been a constant financing partner. They applied for an additional loan for her existing carenderia and to venture into a new field: barbecue selling. Their business allows them to purchase more stocks of drinks and meat for her business. She dreamed that someday her business can be seen not only in Ozamiz city, but also in other places in Misamis Occidental.Their greatest desire is for all their children to finishschool and to have a job for a better future.

loans.use: additional capital for "carenderia" business

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
Alejandrina es socia del Bancomunal San Judas Tadeo.
Alejandrina es conviviente, tiene 49 años, cuatro hijos  25, 24, 20,  y 9 están soleteros y  todos estudian.
Llego de Huanuco a los 16 años, trabajo en casas hasta que se caso, su esposo no quiso que siguiera trabajando, él es albañil, pero hace dos años puso una bodega  abarrotes  en su casa, pero no ganaba mucho, cambio de  giró decidió vender cerveza, gaseosas  y golosina, le deja mas ganancias. 
Desde que esta en Finca, aprendió a ahorrar, tiene mas dinero para  invertir, le gusta las reuniones del Bancomunal por que tiene amigas.   
Necesita un crédito de 1600 soles, para comprar cerveza, gaseosa y galletas,  
El sueño de Alejandrina es que su negocio crezca, para seguir  educando a sus hijos y que todos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Alejandrina is a member of the San Judas Tadeo Communal Bank. Alejandrina lives with her partner, is 49 years old, and has four children who are 25, 24, 20, and 9. All of her children are single and are students. She arrived from Huanuco when she was 16 years old and worked in homes until she got married. Her husband, a bricklayer, did not want her to keep working. Two years ago she started a small grocery story in her home but she did not earn much money. She decided to change things around to sell beer, soft drinks, and sweets to increase her earnings. Since she has been a part of Finca she has learned how to save and she has more money to invest. She likes the bank meetings because she has friends there. She needs a loan of 1600 soles ($500 USD) to buy beer, soft drinks, and cookies. Alejandrina's dream is for her business to grow and to continue educating her children so that they all become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beer, soft drinks, and cookies

loans.name: Maria De Jesus

texts.es: María de Jesús Gonzales F. tiene la edad de 32 años, es soltera y no tiene hijos. La actividad económica de Doña María es la venta de mercadearía en general. Hace más de diez años que se dedica a esta actividad, además Doña María recibe la ayuda de su Mama ya que no tiene tiempo para sus 2 trabajos ya que labora como maestra en una escuela. Doña María tiene los propósitos de brindarle mejoras a su negocio ya que la mayor parte del tiempo es su Mama quien se encuentra en el local. Es por eso que ha solicitado un financiamiento con el fin de invertir en sus productos ya que con esto podrá comprar productos como calzado, ropa y cosméticos. Sus deseos son poseer 2 negocios para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 23.000 córdobas a un plazo de 18 meses.
texts.en:
María de Jesús Gonzales F. is 32 years old, single, and has no children. Maria works selling general merchandise. She has earned her living this way for the past 10 years and she also gets some help from her mother since she doesn’t have time for her two jobs—she also works as a schoolteacher. Maria would like to make improvements to her business since for the most part it is her mother who attends to the store. Because of this she is asking for a loan with the idea of investing it in merchandise like clothing, shoes and cosmetics. She hopes to eventually have 2 locations in order to satisfy the demand of her customers. She is asking for C$ 23.000 córdobas to be repaid in 18 months.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Yanet Liliana

texts.es:
Yanet es socia del Bancomunal Amistad Unida.
Yanet es casada tiene 39 años, un hijo de 11 años que estudia en la escuela estatal.
Yanet trabajaba en una librería con dedicación exclusiva, tuvo que dejar el trabajo porque su hija es enfermiza, tiene soplo al corazón y es asmática, no podía dejarla sola mucho tiempo. Se le presentó la oportunidad de  vender productos por catalogo, ella empezó para probar, han pasado casi dos años y le va muy bien.
Yanet necesita un préstamo de 1400 soles para la compra de productos de belleza por catalogo.
Desde que está en Finca, ha podido juntar un capital que le permiten cubrir gastos, comprar más ofertas, ahora tiene más amiga.  
El sueño de Yanet es comprar su casa, y poner un negocio.
texts.en:
Yanet is a member of the Bancomunal Amistad Unida. Yanet is married and 39 years old. She has an 11-year-old son who goes to public school. Yanet worked full-time in a bookstore but had to quit her job because her daughter is sickly. She has a heart murmur and asthma, and Yanet couldn't leave her by herself that long. She got the opportunity to sell products from a catalog, and decided to try it out. It's been almost two years and she's doing quite well. Yanet needs a loan of 1400 soles to buy beauty products by catalog. Since she's been with Finca, she's been able to get together the money to cover her expenses, take advantage of discounts, and now she has more friends. Yanet's dream is to buy a house and have her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy catalog beauty products

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina M.,  27, is married with 4 children.  She has 6 years of experience in the pork bun business. She sells to the general public 6 days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 145 Tala.  SPBD loans are Lina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase basins, frying pan, flour, yeast, plastic containers, onions,mutton flaps, seasoning oil and soya sauce.

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.ru: Тураходжаева рафоат незакончив свой первый кредит  хочет опять в кредит установить пластиковые окна и двери. Она  первый свой займ удачно погашает и рада что успешно отремонтировала свою квартиру. Она работает в центре здоровья старшей медсестрой. Её сын работает водителем ректора университета. Он помогает ей во время погашения, т.к. заработная Рафоат очень низкая ей необходима помощь со стороны родных. Рафоат благодарна за поддержку и доверие всем инвесторам KIVA.
texts.en:
Although Rafoat T. has not completely paid back her first loan, she would like to take out another loan to install plastic windows and doors. She has successfully paid down her first loan and is happy with the repairs made to her apartment. She holds the post of senior nurse at a health center. Her son work as a driver for the rector of the university. He has helped her to pay down the loan on time, since Rafoat's wages are low and she has had to accept assistance from her relatives. Rafoat is grateful for the support and the trust of Kiva investors.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of plastic windows and door

loans.name: Marinelle

texts.en:
Marinelle B. is from the town of Lallo, Cagayan. She is 24 years old. Marinelle is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Marinelle owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products to the local community.

Marinelle joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marinelle is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of pioneer micro-finance institutions in the Philippines committed to serving the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Zoir

texts.en: Z. Zoir is a young married man with two children. Faced with high unemployment in his country, it proved very hard to find a job and he thus began to start his own business of selling teenagers’ clothes. Fortunately, he made good sales and his business is growing, thanks to the quality of his products and the good service he provides. Zoir now needs a $2000 loan which he will use to buy goods to respond to his customers’ demands. He is very thankful to you for helping him improve his service and the quality of life of his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new summer clothing

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
La señora Martha, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Niño Jesús de Praga”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Yunguyo, Provincia de Chuchito, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 70 años de edad, está casada y es madre de 03 hijos, todos ya independientes,  ella  no tiene estudios, y vive en el Barrio San Borja.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace muchos años,  inició su negocio con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual utilizó para la compra de azúcar para la elaboración de mana (cereal).

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles, para comprar azúcar, maíz, para la elaboración de mana, ella se dedica a la venta de este cereal.

Su mayor sueño es seguir trabajando.

A ella le gustan los encuentros de los Bancos Comunales y los ahorros que ha podido generar.
texts.en:
Señora Martha belongs to the communal bank, "Niño de Jesús de Praga," which is located in the district of Yunguyo, in the province of Chuchito, in the department of Puno. She is 70, is married, and is the mother of 3 children who are all independent. She did not go to school and lives in the San Borja neighborhood. She has worked with Manuela Ramos for many years and started her business with an intial loan of 300 PEN. She used this money to purchase sugar to make mana (a type of cereal). Now she needs a loan of 2,000 PEN, with which she will buy sugar and corn to make mana. She makes a living by selling this cereal. Her biggest dream is to keep working. She likes the meetings her communal bank has and the savings that she earns through it.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sugar and corn

loans.name: Bolivar Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer, “Los Andes” se encuentra un grupo de señoras que se hacen llamar “Bolivar”, ya que todas pertenecen al equipo de fútbol paceño que lleva el mismo nombre, se agruparon hace aproximadamente 3 años, por la necesidad de contar con capital de trabajo que les permita iniciar o mejorar sus negocios y así incrementar sus ingresos que les permita una mejor calidad de vida para ellas y sus familias.
Ahora todas tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de comida, tienda de barrio, venta de cosméticos, venta de mantas, venta de calzados, venta de yuca y confección de chamarras y necesitan el préstamo para la compra de mercadería.
A ellas también les gusta compartir, así que se organizan para saborear un “Apthapi” (cada una prepara comida y trae para compartirlo con el grupo).
texts.en:
In “Los Andes” one of Pro Mujer’s local centers, meets a group of women that call themselves “Bolivar” since they all belong to the La Paz football team which takes the same name. They came together approximately three years ago because of the necessity of gathering working capital that permits them to begin or improve their businesses and increase their income. This allows a better quality of life for them and their families..

Now, they all have their own businesses like the sale of food, a neighborhood shop, the sale of cosmetics, the sale of blankets, the sale of footwear, the sale of cassava, and the making of sheepskin jackets. They need a loan for the purchase of merchandise. They also like to share. As a result they organize themselves in order to taste a “Apthapi” (each one prepares and brings food in order to share it with the group).

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma A. sells onions at Atabadi near Elmina. Emma has a junior high school education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Emma has been selling onions since 2002. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more onions for resale to expand the business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business build a house.

loans.use: To buy more onions for resale to expand the business

loans.name: Emilina

texts.en:
Emeliana is a member of the Mwangata D borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 40 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 7 and 3 years.

Emiliana started her own business selling vibatari 3 years ago,she works 8 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 40,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Emeliana`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more material for her business.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Emeliana hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Chadi

texts.en:
Chadi is a 27-year-old engaged man. He lives in Bint Jbeil in southern Lebanon, where he works as an electrician. Chadi requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy some tools and gear for his work and also to save some money for his wedding. This is Chadi’s second year as a micro-credit client.

Chadi knows how to run his business and he has been working for six years now. He is unique because of his skills and expertise in solving electricity problems. His clients are mainly friends, neighbors and tourists. He hopes to get married in the future.

loans.use: To buy some tools and gear for his work and also to save some money for his wedding

loans.name: Toud

texts.en: Toud P., age 32, is married with four school-aged children. She lives with her husband in Battambong Province. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling groceries, typically earning US $6 per day. Her husband is involved in the agriculture sector of growing rice and fruit trees, earning an income of US $5.5 per day. Both of them have to work hard everyday to ensure a good living for their family and her four children. Consequently, she is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase more plots of farmland to grow rice for more output to meet the current market’s requirement. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: buy plots of farmland

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is engaged in hog raising business in the village of Addalam Jones, Isabela. She is married to Antonio Jr. who is a farmer. She would like to maintain her hog raising business by providing enough supply of feeds for her hogs.  For this, she is borrowing PHP4,000 as additional capital to pursue her plans. 

Rosie and Antonio Jr. have two children who are still studying. The eldest is John Anthony-14 years old and Rex-13 years old. Rosie hopes that her two children could finish their schooling. The couple hopes for the support of the KIVA lenders to their business

loans.use: Additional capital for business maintenance

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is married to Ruben and they are blessed with four children. She and her husband successfully send their children to school and two are already college graduates with the assistance of the vegetable-vending business.

Virginia and her husband plant vegetables and, after harvesting them, they sell them wholesale in the market. The income from their business is carefully budgeted to meet the needs of their family and to pay the school fees of their children. Virginia dreams that her two younger children will finish their studies. She and her husband are doing their best for the welfare of their children.

Virginia wants to borrow PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of their vegetables business and for them to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs they need. They are hoping that they will have a good yield and be able to increase their profit.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Vicente Guerrero 2 Group

texts.es:
La Señora Maricela Zúñiga A. es originaria y vecina D. la Localidad D. Cruz GranD., situada en la Costa Chica del Estado D. Guerrero.
Tiene 30 años es una persona casada con 4 hijos que viven con ella D. 14, 12, 8 y 5 años D. edad, todos sus hijos estudian diferentes grados escolares en la localidad.
DesD. hace 5 años que tiene una pequeña tienda D. venta D. comestibles y artículos D. primera necesidad, su tienda siempre ha sido muy pequeña ya que no contaba con apoyos crediticios, hace 4 meses recibió un crédito D. Fundación Realidad por la cantidad D. 3,000 meses el cual lo pagó en un plazo D. 4 meses y le sirvió para ampliar un poco su tienda, en la actualidad recibió un segundo crédito D. 5,000 pesos tiene intenciones a través D. los créditos D. seguir desarrollando su comercio.
D. esta actividad apoya con el gasto familiar a su esposo para la educación D. sus hijos. Su esposo es empleado D. una compañía D. refrescos, pero su sueldo no alcanza para todos los gastos familiares.
Con el fin D. poder acceder a un crédito es por lo que formaron un grupo D. 10 mujeres D. la misma comunidad, cada una con diferentes actividades productivas ya que es la forma D. adquirir un préstamo con Fundación Realidad.
No contaba con experiencia en créditos, pero esta muy contenta D. los beneficios que ha recibido, y desea seguir con los créditos desarrollando cada vez mas su negocio, también desea seguir con las compañeras D. su grupo con las cuales se siente contenta.

Maricela Zuñiga A.	5,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Dolores M. B.	        3,000.00	Venta D. comestibles 
Lucia A. R.	        2,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Adalberta R. M.	        1,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Agripina R. R.	        8,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Dioema Crisóstomo C.	8,000.00	Venta D. productos naturistas
Paula Y. L.	        6,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Petra D. Jesús Pérez	        8,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Isabel G. M.	        2,000.00	Venta D. plátanos D. la región
Roberta G. M.	        3,000.00	Venta D. ropa
texts.en:
Sra. Maricela Zúñiga A. is a native and resident of the community of Cruz GranD., which is located in Costa Chica in the State of Guerrero. She is 30 years old, married, and has 4 children (ages 14, 12, 8, and 5). All of them attend school in the community and are in different graD. levels.

For 5 years, Maricela has managed a business selling groceries and basic necessities. Her shop has always been small because she never received the assistance of a loan. Four months ago, she obtained a loan from Fundación Realidad in the amount of 3000 MXN and used it to expand her store a little bit. That loan has been repaid. Today she will receive a second loan of 5000 MXN so that she can continue to develop her business. The income from her store covers her family’s expenses, while her husband’s earnings are used to pay for their children’s education. He is employed at a soft drink company, but his salary is not enough to pay for all of the household expenses.

In order to access a loan, the group had to consist of 10 women from the same community. Each member must engage in a productive business activity, since this is a prerequisite for receiving a loan from Fundación Realidad. With no previous credit experience, these ladies are pleased with the benefits they have received. They hope to continue in their development because they want to be eligible for future business loans. In addition, they are happy to be working with one another and hope they can continue as a group.

The breakdown of the group loan is as follows: Maricela Zuñiga A. requests 5000 MXN to sell food. Dolores M. B. requests 3000 MXN to sell food. Lucia A. R. requests 2000 MXN to sell food. Adalberta R. M. requests 1000 MXN to sell food. Agripina R. R. requests 8000 MXN to sell food. Dioema Crisóstomo C. requests 8000 MXN to sell natural products. Paula Y. L. requests 6000 MXN to sell food. Petra D. Jesús Pérez requests 8000 MXN to sell food. Isabel G. M. requests 2000 MXN to sell regional bananas. Roberta G. M. requests 3000 MXN to sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to buy merchandise for their respective businesses

location.town: Cruz Grande, Municipio Florencio Villareal, Estado

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren D. is a 45-year-old single mother of two children. She currently lives with her 14-year-old son in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter is 19 years old and is a student in the National University of Mongolia in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Purevsuren has been running a small meat retail stall in the local food market for the last nine years. She usually purchases mutton and beef at wholesale prices and sells in small pieces to local customers. She says that she is very experienced in the business and has her own loyal customers who always purchase their meat supply from her.

The business has been stabilized and she further notes that she is still working hard to make sure that she will be able to make enough money to pay her daughter's tuition.

She requests a loan to purchase more meat for her business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: to purchase more meat for her business

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Mr. Oem S. is 34 years of age and currently works on his farm, planting different kinds of crops. His wife appears in the picture above, and she earns a living as a hairdresser.  This couple has been married for some years and have three young children, who are going to school. Oem S.’s wife doesn’t have enough materials to use to give good service. That is why Oem S. is applying for a loan to buy more hairdressing materials which will allow his wife to improve her service and be efficient.

loans.use: To buy more hairdressing materials

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna J. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 40 years old, and is widowed with no children. To make a living, Edna owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Edna has been engaged in her business for many years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Edna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose G. is from the village of Libag sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 49 years old. Rose is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rose owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Rose has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. Rose is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make her products for sale. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Rose from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Hy Kruy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hy K. is 48 years old and the president of her village bank that consists of 20 people, all of whom live in Kandal Kaoh Touch village in Kandal province. The entire membership of the group will use this loan to support their businesses.

Mrs. Hy K. is a mother of three children, one is employed in a garment factory and the others are students in the local school. Mrs. Hy K. is a basket maker who does not earn enough income to support her family. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it and so she is requesting a loan from AMK to buy more bamboo to make baskets. Her husband, Mr. Chin Thong, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field on which he cultivates rice.

loans.use: To buy more bamboo to make baskets.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en: Carmelita P. earns her living by candy making. She is a 53-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Talubangi, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. Carmelita’s husband, Armando, 55 years old, helps run the business by delivering the finished product to a local market and other general stores. They have three children who are between 23 and 27 years old: two of them work and one already has a family. Carmelita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family's income by making candy. Now she earns an average monthly income of 54,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her business activities. Carmelita is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her candy business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 17th loan, in the amount of 20,000 PHP, which she intends to use making candy. Carmelita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for a candy business

loans.name: Omukyepatiko Junction Group A, Kihihi

texts.en: T. Doreen, at the top left, is the same lady that is standing at the far right. She is the leader of her lending group in Kihihi. She is 30 years old and divorced with two children aged 10 and 9 years. They are both in primary school. She also takes care of her sister. Doreen is a hard working lady who has been selling old/used clothes from Kiruruma trading centre for five years. Her profits amount to 50,000/= a week. She ensures that her goods are of good quality and she uses her good customer care skills. She hopes to expand her business with more quality stock so that she can pay for her children’s education since she is a single mother. She needs a loan to be able to buy other clothes for resale.

loans.use: Buying more used clothing for resale.

loans.name: Leydith

texts.es:
La Sra. Leydith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Orquídeas” del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín y Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 32 años y es madre de 01 bebe.

El espíritu luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas de salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio de venta de anticuchos en las fueras de su casa, donde poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en este tipo de actividad.  Sus ventas lo realiza  diariamente  a partir de las 6:00pm. Lleva aun poco tiempo trabajando en este tipo de actividad y se siente muy contenta con lo que hace.
 
Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará insumos cómo arroz en sacos, huevos, gallinas criollas para sus juanes y pollos desviscerados para sus anticuchos, asimismo utensilios de cocina para brindar un servicio de calidad.  

Leydith, se siente muy tranquila y contenta con lo que hace  y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Leydith, 32, is a member of the “Las Orquídeas” (The Orchids) communal bank, which is located in Tarapoto, San Martín province, San Martín department. She is single and has a baby. Her tenacious spirit and desire to get ahead in life through her own efforts and initiative have led her to set up an anticuchos (skewered grilled meat) sales stand outside her home. She has gradually become better known among her customers and today she tells us that she does quite well with her business. She opens for business at 6:00pm every day. She has been in this line of work for a short time and is very happy with what she does. She will use this, 1,000.00 new sol, loan to buy ingredients, like: sacks of rice, eggs, chickens for her Juanes (a rice, chicken, olive and cooked egg dish), dressed chickens for her anticuchos, as well as kitchen utensils to provide better service. Leydith is tranquil and happy with what she does and is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her meet her goals and helping to make her dreams come true.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for meals preparation.

loans.name: Gilberto Rafael

texts.es:
Gilberto Rafael M. Hernández de 50 años de edad vive en el barrio Moras IV Etapa del municipio de Soledad, municipio al sur de Barranquilla y dice que su barrio es relativamente sano con vecinos muy colaboradores. Está casado con un hijo de 28 años de edad. Tiene un negocio en su casa donde vende mercancía, especialmente ropa y calzado, junto con su esposa y justamente quiere financiación por valor de $1.600.000 para comprar  la mercancía descrita.
Antes Gilberto trabajaba con muebles y productos de hogar y  se desempeñó también como mensajero durante 17 años hasta el año 1997, cuando se retiró por quiebra de la empresa. Al recibir su  liquidación empezó a viajar a Magangue, municipio en el departamento de Bolívar en las orillas del río Magdalena, el río más importante de Colombia. De Magangue Gilberto traía pescado que vendía y también su esposa elaboraba y vendía  bolis, una variedad de helado colombiana, que actualmente ella vende en el Estadio Metropolitano cuando hay partidos de Futbol. Simultáneamente además de los bolis, los dos venden en su casa helados, dulces y mercancía como ropa, calzado y detalles.
Este es su segundo crédito e invirtió el anterior en mejorar el surtido de mercancía en el negocio. Más adelante, sueña con tener un negocio más grande con buena localización: montarlo es también su mayor desafío ya que requiere dinero. Además, su meta es implemetarle un taller a su hijo, que está estudiando cursos de tecnólogo de autotécnica y técnico en gas vehicular en el SENA, órgano nacional que fomenta el aprendizaje.
texts.en:
Gilberto Rafael M. Hernández is 50 years old and lives in the Moras IV Etapa neighborhood in the town of Soledad, south of Barranquilla. He says that his neighborhood is relatively safe with very cooperative neighbors. He is married and has a 28 year old son. He has a business in his home where he sells merchandise, espcecially clothing and shoes. He does this with his wife and it is why he is asking for a loan of $1.600.000, to buy the described merchandise. Gilberto used to work with furniture and products for the home. He also worked as a messenger for 17 years until 1997, when he stopped because the business went broke. When he received his severance, he began to travel to Magangue, a town in the department of Bolívar on the shores of the Magdalena river, the most important river in Colombia. Gilberto would bring fish from Magangue which he would sell. His wife also would make and sell bolis, a type of Colombian ice cream. She sells it now in the Estadio Metropolitano when there are soccer games.
